timeline.author: Nashatyrev

replies.bodyText: You'll get an IOException of some form on all systems trying to actually read a directory.  The point of this behaviour is that this method returns an empty optional if the file couldn't be found, it throws an IOException if it can't be read.  Since directories do exist but can't be read, the expected behaviour is to throw IOException (or any subclass).  Both ways fail, but this way gives a much more accurate error message to the user.
replies.author: ajsutton

replies.bodyText: Ah I see, on Windows it throws earlier than on UNIX.  Throwing is still the right answer rather than returning empty, just need to update the test to handle the exception being thrown either from load or from the read call.
